message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased mobility at the neck suggests that the ligaments and vertebrae were damaged, and the spinal cord at C6 level would show the presence of cuneate and gracilis fasciculi, which are located at this level and contain sensory fibers from the upper body. Lateral horns are located in the thoracic and upper lumbar segments, and gray matter enlargement is seen in conditions such as polio. Least amount of white matter is not a feature of any specific spinal cord level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased mobility at the neck suggests a cervical spinal cord injury. Among the options, only (D) is true of the spinal cord at C6 as the cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present at this level. The lateral horns are not prominent in the cervical spinal cord, the amount of white matter is greater than gray matter, and there is gray matter enlargement in the anterior horns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present at the level of the cervical spinal cord, and their presence is unrelated to the mobility of the neck. The other options do not relate specifically to the level of the cervical spinal cord at C6.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present at the cervical spinal cord level, while options A, B, and C are not features seen at this level. The increased mobility at the neck could indicate a spinal cord injury that affects the integrity of the structures in this region.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At the C6 level of the spinal cord, the cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present. Increased mobility at the neck may suggest damage to the cervical vertebrae, but it does not provide information about the anatomy of the spinal cord at a specific level. Options A and B are not specific to the C6 level, while option C suggests a pathology such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis or syringomyelia, but is not a normal feature of the spinal cord.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormally increased mobility at the neck suggests injury at the spinal cord level. Among the options, only cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present at the cervical spinal cord level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased mobility at the neck suggests injury at the cervical level. At the C6 level, cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present, which are both sensory tracts. Prominent lateral horns are present at the thoracic and lumbar levels. The least amount of white matter is seen at the sacral level. Absence of gray matter enlargement is not a specific feature of the C6 level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cuneate and Gracilis fasciculi are both present at C6 spinal cord level. The other options (prominent lateral horns, least amount of white matter, absence of gray matter enlargement) are not specific to C6 level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased mobility at the neck and specific level of C6 suggest a possibility of injury to the dorsal columns, which contain the cuneate and gracilis fasciculi. Therefore, (D) is the correct answer. Prominent lateral horns are seen in thoracic spinal cord levels, the least amount of white matter is seen in the spinal cord level of conus medullaris and Absence of gray matter enlargement is not a specific feature of any spinal cord level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. At the C6 level of the spinal cord, the cuneate and gracilis fasciculi are present, responsible for conducting sensation from the upper and lower extremities to the brain. A and B are incorrect as lateral horns are more prominent at T1-L2 and the least amount of white matter is at C3-C4. C is also incorrect as a normal spinal cord at this level would have some enlargement of the gray matter due to the presence of motor neurons responsible for upper limb movements.
